It may be observed that H_{p,q}(z) represents the sum of the residues of the poles of the integrand in (16.5.1) at s=-a_{j},-a_{j}-1,\dots , j=1,\dots,p , provided that these poles are all simple, that is, no two of the a_{j} differ by an integer.
(Ifthis condition is violated, then the definition of H_{p,q}(z) has to be modified so that the residues are those associated with the multiple poles.
In consequence, logarithmic terms may appear.
See (15.8.8) for an example.)
In this subsection we assume that none of a_{1},a_{2},\dots,a_{p} is a nonpositive integer.

The formal series (16.11.2) for H_{q+1,q}(z) converges if \left|z\right|>1 , and \left({\textstyle\ifrac{\prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q+1}\Gamma\left(a_{\ell}\right) }{\prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q}\Gamma\left(b_{\ell}\right)}}\right){{}_{q+1}F_{q}} \left({a_{1},\dots,a_{q+1}\atop b_{1},\dots,b_{q}};z\right)=H_{q+1,q}(-z), if |\operatorname{ph}\left(-z\right)|\leq\pi; compare (16.8.8).

As z\to\infty in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi , \left({\textstyle\ifrac{\prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q}\Gamma\left(a_{\ell}\right)}{ \prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q}\Gamma\left(b_{\ell}\right)}}\right){{}_{q}F_{q}} \left({a_{1},\dots,a_{q}\atop b_{1},\dots,b_{q}};z\right)\sim H_{q,q}(z{ \mathrm{e}^{\mp\pi\mathrm{i}}})+E_{q,q}(z).

Here the upper or lower signs are chosen according as z lies in the upper or lower half-plane; in consequence, in the fractional powers (ยง4.2(iv)) of ze^{\mp\pi i} its phases are \operatorname{ph}z\mp\pi , respectively.
(Either sign may be used when \operatorname{ph}z=0 since the first term on the right-hand side becomes exponentially small compared with the second term.)
Explicit representations for the coefficients c_{k} are given in Volkmer and Wood (2014).
The special case a_{1}=1 , p=q=2 is discussed in Kim (1972).

As z\to\infty in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi , \left({\textstyle\ifrac{\prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q-1}\Gamma\left(a_{\ell}\right) }{\prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q}\Gamma\left(b_{\ell}\right)}}\right){{}_{q-1}F_{q}} \left({a_{1},\dots,a_{q-1}\atop b_{1},\dots,b_{q}};-z\right)\sim H_{q-1,q}(z)+ E_{q-1,q}(ze^{-\pi\mathrm{i}})+E_{q-1,q}(ze^{\pi\mathrm{i}}), with the same conventions on the phases of ze^{\mp\pi i}.

As z\to\infty in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi , \left({\textstyle\ifrac{\prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{p}\Gamma\left(a_{\ell}\right)}{ \prod\limits_{\ell=1}^{q}\Gamma\left(b_{\ell}\right)}}\right){{}_{p}F_{q}} \left({a_{1},\dots,a_{p}\atop b_{1},\dots,b_{q}};-z\right)\sim E_{p,q}(ze^{- \pi\mathrm{i}})+E_{p,q}(ze^{\pi\mathrm{i}}), with the same conventions on the phases of ze^{\mp\pi i}.

If z is fixed and |\operatorname{ph}\left(1-z\right)|<\pi , then for each nonnegative integer m {{}_{p+1}F_{p}}\left({a_{1}+r,\dots,a_{k-1}+r,a_{k},\dots,a_{p+1}\atop b_{1}+r ,\dots,b_{k}+r,b_{k+1},\dots,b_{p}};z\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}\frac{{\left(a_{1 }+r\right)_{n}}\cdots{\left(a_{k-1}+r\right)_{n}}{\left(a_{k}\right)_{n}} \cdots{\left(a_{p+1}\right)_{n}}}{{\left(b_{1}+r\right)_{n}}\cdots{\left(b_{k} +r\right)_{n}}{\left(b_{k+1}\right)_{n}}\cdots{\left(b_{p}\right)_{n}}}\frac{z ^{n}}{n!}+O\left(\frac{1}{r^{m}}\right) , as r\to+\infty.
Here k can have any integer value from 1 to p.

Also if p<q , then {{}_{p}F_{q}}\left({a_{1}+r,\dots,a_{p}+r\atop b_{1}+r,\dots,b_{q}+r};z\right) =\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}\frac{{\left(a_{1}+r\right)_{n}}\cdots{\left(a_{p}+r\right)_{ n}}}{{\left(b_{1}+r\right)_{n}}\cdots{\left(b_{q}+r\right)_{n}}}\frac{z^{n}}{n !}+O\left(\frac{1}{r^{(q-p)m}}\right) , again as r\to+\infty.
For these and other results seeKnottnerus (1960).
See also Luke (1969a, ยง7.3).

Asymptotic expansions for the polynomials {{}_{p+2}F_{q}}\left(-r,r+a_{0},\mathbf{a};\mathbf{b};z\right) as r\to\infty through integer values are given in Fields and Luke (1963b, a) and Fields (1965).
